{{Infobox software | name = BugTracker.NET | logo = | screenshot = | caption = | developer = [http://www.ifdefined.com/bugtrackernet.html Corey Trager] | latest_release_version = 3.5.7 | latest_release_date = {{release date and age|2012|06|17}} | operating_system = [[Microsoft Windows]] | operating_system_desc = | genre = [[Bug tracking system]] | license = [[GNU General Public License]] | website = http://ifdefined.com/bugtrackernet.html }} '''BugTracker.NET''' is a free [[open source]] web-based [[bug tracking system]] and customer support [[issue tracking system]]. It was created by Corey Trager starting in 2002, using [[ASP.NET]], [[C Sharp (programming language)|C#]], and [[Microsoft SQL Server]].
BugTracker.NET is [[free software]], licensed under the terms of the [[GNU General Public License]] (GPL). It is built on other open source software including the full text search engine [[Lucene.net|Lucene.NET]], the rich text editor [[CKEditor]], the JavaScript library [[jQuery]], and the [[MIME]] parser SharpMimeTools.
It supports version control integration with the open source version control systems [[Subversion (software)|Subversion]],<ref>{{cite web|author=Gurkan Yeniceri|title=Poor Man's TFS|url=http://analystdeveloper.com/blogs/gurkaneng/archive/2005/09/20/1465.aspx}}</ref> [[Git (software)|Git]], and [[Mercurial (software)|Mercurial]].
==Security== Version 3.5.6 2012/02/23 (SVN revision 653) {{Citation/make link|http://sourceforge.net/projects/btnet/files/btnet_3_5_6_release_notes.txt/view|Bugtracker.net changelog}} Fixed security hole whereby BugTracker.NET user belonging to an organization marked "external" could view posts marked "Visible to internal users only". Thanks to Jaroslav Kabrt for finding this.
Version 3.5.1 2011/06/11 (SVN revision 619) {{Citation/make link|http://sourceforge.net/projects/btnet/files/btnet_3_5_1_release_notes.txt/view|Bugtracker.net changelog}} An injection vulnerability was found in one of the installation files, however if followed the guideline to set up the tool no installation should be vulnerable since the vulnerable file should be deleted.
Version 3.4.5 2010/11/29 (SVN revision 578) {{Citation/make link|http://sourceforge.net/projects/btnet/files/btnet_3_4_5_release_notes.txt/view|Bugtracker.net changelog}} Core security technologies<ref>[http://coresecurity.com coresecurity.com]</ref> found some serious security vulnerabilities. If the bugs.aspx was publicly available to the Internet or not trusted visitors.
Version 3.4.4 2010/08/21 (SVN revision 566) {{Citation/make link|http://sourceforge.net/projects/btnet/files/btnet_3_4_4_release_notes.txt/view|Bugtracker.net changelog}} There's only one change, a fix to an SQL injection vulnerability in search.aspx. Thanks to Mark van Tilburg for letting me know. This vulnerability is several years old. {{Citation/make link|http://van-tilburg.info/security/BugTracker.NET.v3.4.3.txt|Security Advisory}} This security issue only occurs if custom fields are used, if no custom fields are used this vulnerability cannot be misused.
The last known critical vulnerability for BugTracker.NET was in 2005, when [[Secunia]] warned of [[SQL injection]] vulnerabilities in version 2.0. This was fixed in version 2.02.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://secunia.com/advisories/14722/|date=2005-03-30|accessdate=2008-01-15|title=BugTracker.NET Multiple SQL Injection Vulnerabilities}}</ref>
In January 2008, Secunia issued a less critical advisory concerning [[cross-site request forgery]] and [[cross-site scripting]] vulnerabilities for versions prior to 2.72.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://secunia.com/advisories/28481/|date=2008-01-14|accessdate=2008-01-15|title=BugTracker.NET Script Insertion and Cross-Site Request Forgery Vulnerabilities}}</ref>
As of 2009-06-11, no new security vulnerabilities have been reported by Secunia<ref>{{cite web|url=http://secunia.com/advisories/product/4856/?task=advisories|date=2009-06-11|accessdate=2009-06-11|title=BugTracker.NET 2.x Advisories by product}}</ref>
